Two letters of recommendation. Personal statement addressing your experience working with English learners, your reasons for pursuing a graduate certificate, and your career goals. Resume or curriculum vitae (CV). For non-native speakers of English, a score report of the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Pearson Test of English Academic (PTE A), or Duolingo is required.
Department: College of Education
Description: The Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL) graduate certificate provides post-baccalaureate students and community members a program of study in the theory and practice of second language teaching. The TESOL certificate is an excellent option for those who wish to enhance their professional credentials for teaching English as a second or foreign language in the U.S. or abroad. The certificate may be completed on its own or concurrently with a Master's degree. Students who complete the certificate gain a background in linguistic theory, second language acquisition research, and teaching methodologies.

ProgramName: Graduate Certificate in Teaching: K-12 and Secondary Programs
EnglishScore: International graduate students must meet English proficiency requirements. Accepted tests and minimum scores include: TOEFL iBT score of 79 (with minimum subscores of 17), IELTS score of 6.5 (with no subscore lower than 6.0), Duolingo English Test score of 110, PTE Academic score of 53, or successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112.
Requirements: Apply through the College of Graduate Studies and Research. Submit ALL official college and university transcripts showing a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher. For individuals with a GPA below 3.0, please contact the program coordinator. Provide evidence of a degree-equivalent major from a regionally accredited college or university in the content area for which the applicant is seeking licensure OR provide evidence of having passed the appropriate Minnesota Teacher Licensure Examination (MTLE) content exam. Submit a one-page essay outlining your commitment to the profession and reasons for wanting to become a teacher. Provide the name and email address of two references. They will receive an email from the university with a link to a recommendation form. Submit a résumé. Interview with program faculty.
Department: College of Education
Concentration: Communication Arts and Literature (grades 5-12), Mathematics (grades 5-12), Science (grades 5-8), Chemistry (grades 9-12), Earth Science (grades 9-12), Life Science (grades 9-12), Physics (grades 9-12), Social Studies (grades 5-12)
Description: The K-12 and Secondary Programs (KSP) department provides instruction for undergraduate and graduate teacher candidates pursuing a teaching license in a variety of content areas at the middle and high school levels. Our teacher candidates complete content coursework in their major department, and pedagogy coursework in our department. Upon graduation, our teacher candidates have earned a bachelor’s degree in their content area, as well as a Minnesota teaching license. The Graduate Certificate in Teaching (GCT) is a 24-credit graduate level program leading to a Minnesota teaching license in one of the following content areas: Communication Arts and Literature (grades 5-12), Mathematics (grades 5-12), Science (grades 5-8), Chemistry (grades 9-12), Earth Science (grades 9-12), Life Science (grades 9-12), Physics (grades 9-12), Social Studies (grades 5-12). This program is intended for those individuals who already possess a Bachelor’s degree and are seeking a teaching license. Coursework is determined through a transcript analysis and is unique to each student. The graduate certificate requires a minimum of 24 graduate credits.
Accredidation: The K-12 and Secondary Programs department is part of the College of Education which is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). Our programs are also approved by the Minnesota Professional Educator Licensing and Standards Board (PELSB).

ProgramName: Graduate Certificate in Teaching: Reading
EnglishScore: Graduate applicants who have not completed their post-secondary education in an English-speaking country must demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted methods include TOEFL iBT (minimum 79 with 17 on speaking and writing), TOEFL PBT (minimum 550), IELTS (minimum 6.0 with no band below 5.0), PTE Academic (minimum 53), Duolingo English Test (minimum 100), or completion of ELS Level 112. This requirement may be waived for students who have completed 24 semester credits from a regionally accredited U.S. college or university or earned a bachelor's degree from a country where English is the official language.
Requirements: Completed application for graduate study. Official transcript showing an earned baccalaureate degree from a regionally accredited institution with a GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. A current Minnesota teaching license.
Department: College of Education
Description: The Teaching: Reading Graduate Certificate Program is designed for teachers who hold a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. This graduate certificate provides an emphasis area in reading and leads to the K-12 Reading Teacher licensure. It does not lead to a master's degree. Students may opt to complete a master's degree by applying certificate credits to the Master of Science in Reading program. Courses in this certificate may be applied to the Master of Science in Reading degree program.
Accredidation: The Teaching: Reading Graduate Certificate Program is part of the College of Education which is accredited by the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education (NCATE).

ProgramName: Graduate Certificate in Teaching: Special Education
EnglishScore: All applicants, regardless of citizenship, must demonstrate English proficiency. Minimum scores accepted for admission to Minnesota State Mankato are: TOEFL iBT score of 61, IELTS score of 5.5, PTE Academic score of 47, or Duolingo English Test (DET) score of 95. Successful completion of ELS Level 112 is also accepted.
Requirements: A bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited college or university. A minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale for the last 60 semester credits of undergraduate coursework. Students applying for the Graduate Certificate are required to submit an application and be accepted into the College of Graduate Studies and Research. The application is located online at mnsu.edu/apply. Submit an official transcript from the institution where the bachelor's degree was earned. Must be admitted to the Professional Education sequence. Complete and pass the MTLE Basic Skills Tests (Reading, Writing, and Mathematics). Note: A waiver may be requested from this requirement if an applicant meets the criteria outlined on the waiver form. Submit two letters of recommendation from professional or academic sources that can speak to your professional dispositions and academic potential. These are submitted as part of the application to the College of Graduate Studies. Submit a one-page statement of purpose explaining your reason for pursuing this graduate certificate and your commitment to working with individuals with disabilities. This is submitted as part of the application to the College of Graduate Studies. Must demonstrate proficiency in Oral and Written Communications, College Level Math, Critical Thinking and Information Technology through coursework taken within the last ten years or through examination.
Department: College of Education
Concentration: Academic and Behavioral Strategist (ABS), Developmental Disabilities (DD), Emotional/Behavioral Disorders (EBD), and Learning Disabilities (LD)
Description: The Graduate Certificate in Teaching: Special Education program is intended for individuals who hold an unexpired Minnesota teaching license and are interested in earning an initial or additional teaching license in one of the following special education licensure areas: Academic and Behavioral Strategist (ABS), Developmental Disabilities (DD), Emotional/Behavioral Disorders (EBD), and Learning Disabilities (LD). The program offers both initial and additional licensure pathways at the graduate level. Those who complete the certificate will meet the coursework requirements for licensure in one of the four licensure areas. They will also meet the state requirement of having a core skill set in the other three disability categories, as well as meeting the reading requirement for licensure in special education. The certificate leads to eligibility for a teaching license upon meeting all Minnesota Professional Educator Licensing and Standards Board (PELSB) requirements, including student teaching and passing the required exams.
Accredidation: All of our programs are accredited by the Minnesota Professional Educator Licensing and Standards Board (PELSB).

ProgramName: Graduate Certificate in Technical Communication
EnglishScore: For non-native speakers of English, one of the following: TOEFL iBT score of 79 or higher, IELTS score of 6.0 or higher, Duolingo score of 100 or higher, PTE Academic score of 53 or higher, or ELS Level 112 Certificate of Completion.
Requirements: The certificate program in Technical Communication is open to anyone who has earned a bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. Applicants may be concurrently enrolled in other graduate programs at MNSU. To be admitted, students must be accepted by the College of Graduate Studies and Research. Application information may be found at the College of Graduate Studies website. To apply to the Technical Communication Graduate Certificate Program, students must apply online at GradCAS. For more specific instructions, follow the directions on the GradCAS website. Applicants must submit an application form, a statement of purpose, and one transcript from each college and university attended. No GRE score is required for admission to the Technical Communication Graduate Certificate Program.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The 12-credit online Technical Communication Graduate Certificate program has been designed for working professionals who want to enhance their careers with advanced communication skills. Coursework is focused on the knowledge and skills needed to design, compose, and edit technical and professional documents.

ProgramName: Postgraduate Certificate in Aging Studies
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English language proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT score of 79 (with minimum subscores of 17); IELTS score of 6.5 (with no subscore below 5.5); Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic score of 53; Duolingo English Test score of 110; or completion of ELS English Language Center's Level 112.
Requirements: In addition to the University's admission requirements, this program requires: Application for Admission. Statement of Purpose. A one to two page essay outlining professional and educational goals and how this certificate will help achieve those goals. It should also describe the applicant’s experience in the aging field. The statement of purpose will be evaluated on the quality of writing and the congruence of applicant goals with program goals. Bachelor’s degree. From a regionally accredited university or college with a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Two letters of recommendation. From people who can attest to applicant’s potential for success in graduate study.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Postgraduate Certificate in Aging Studies provides an opportunity for individuals who have already earned a bachelor's degree to complete a specialized interdisciplinary course of study in aging. The program is specifically tailored for individuals who are either currently working with or who plan to work with older adults. The program offers maximum flexibility as it is offered completely online. The certificate consists of 12 credits including 3 required credits (Aging and the Life Course) and 9 elective credits. No other certificate program in aging studies is available in Minnesota, and few are available in neighboring states. Students who have completed or who are concurrently completing a graduate degree at Minnesota State Mankato are not eligible for the post-graduate certificate in aging studies.
